title-group.article-title: A Proposal to Improve the VAT Treatment of Housing in the European Union

abstract.p: The treatment of housing is one of the most difficult issues under the VATs in the EU. Ideally, rents and rental values should be taxed just like other consumer goods and services, but doing so would present formidable practical and political difficulties. Under a second-best approach, the value of newly created residential (and other) property is taxed as a proxy for the VAT that should be payable on the flow of housing (building) services. This implies, however, that future increases (and decreases) in the value of the exempt property are left out of the VAT base. To remedy this defect, this paper recommends taxing the increases (refunding the tax related to decreases) realised at the time of sale of the exempt used property. This VAT should replace the current transfer, registration and stamp duties, which are highly distortionary. Beyond that, the VATs in various member states can be improved by limiting the exemption for all used immovable property to housing, by taxing land and by applying the standard rate more widely than is currently the case.

p.mixed-citation: Unless otherwise indicated, references to increases in property values should be understood to include decreases, which would involve VAT refunds.
Unless the context requires otherwise, references to transfer duty include registration and stamp duties levied on the same base.
See European Commission (2010a), as well as the accompanying Commission Staff Working Document (European Commission, 2010b).
The following paragraphs draw on Cnossen (1996).

It is quite another matter that land is not a produced input - that its supply is fixed (except perhaps in Holland), so that taxing land ownership is taxing an economic rent (Mirrlees et al., 2011, chapter 16). Accordingly, the tax would be capitalised in the value of the land without any effect on economic activity. But this feature calls for a separate land or land value tax, not a VAT. Under a VAT, the tax on land would be washed out if the land is used for taxable activities by taxable persons, but not if used or owned by non-taxable persons.

The rationale for taxing rental values under the income tax runs parallel to that under a pure VAT. Rather than earning a return on his house in the market, on which he would be taxed, the owner-occupier offers the return to himself as investor, which should be included in his income tax assessment. Taxing this return under the income tax as well as the VAT is not a form of double taxation, just as the application of the VAT to the consumption of a market-earned rental charge, on which income tax has been paid, is not considered double taxation. The application of both taxes arises because owner-occupied houses are an investment as well as a consumption good.

In this respect, the treatment of immovable property differs from the treatment of other consumer durables, such as new cars, which are taxed in full if purchased by a consumer (just like newly built residential property), but whose lease is also taxed (unlike housing rentals).

Poddar (2010) contains a numerical illustration of the equivalence between a VAT on the present discounted value of rents and rental values and its 'prepayment' through a VAT on the value of newly constructed residential premises.

in Italy, duplication and non-transparency have reached such proportions that the government has legislated a replacement tax (see Table 2), purportedly in lieu of the registration duty, stamp duty, mortgage tax, cadastral tax and the duty on official concessions for medium- and long-term loans.

Elsewhere, the Australian states impose stamp duty on the transfer of immovable property, differentiated by state, property category (principal residences may attract reduced rates) and purchase price. There is no link between the federal VAT and the state stamp duty. A study by the Property Council of Australia (2003) concluded that the abolition of stamp duty on leases would be highly desirable. In Canada, most provinces impose land transfer taxes, often at graduated rates. New Zealand does not levy transfer or stamp duties.

For the taxation of land in New Zealand, see Harley (2007); for the treatment of immovable property in New Zealand, see Smith (2007). Australia's goods and services tax (GST) treatment of immovable property is reviewed by Evans (2007). The situations in both countries are compared by Millar (2010), who holds a view contrary to the one held in this paper.

For more on these schemes, see Cnossen (1998, chapter 9).

The Australian GST margin scheme was reviewed in 2010. See Australian Treasury (2010a and 2010b).

Conrad (2010) believes that VAT should be levied on the selling price and that a credit should be allowed for the inflation-adjusted VAT on the purchase price, but this appears difficult to reconcile with the cash-flow nature of the VAT. For more details on this 'S-tax' ('s' for 'stock'), see Conrad and Grozav (2008).

These valuations are also used for income tax, municipal property tax and inheritance tax purposes. The rental value of owner-occupied property is subject to the progressive income tax, but effective rates are low because taxable rental values are computed using lower percentages applied to rated values than would accord with arm's-length rates. Since mortgage interest is fully deductible, the income tax treatment of rental values results in a sizeable net subsidy to homeowners.
